metadata.summary: Apple Developer Documentation page describing split views, a UI component that manages the presentation of multiple adjacent panes of content. The document covers best practices, platform-specific considerations for iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, visionOS, and watchOS, along with developer resources and related documentation links.

content.text: Split views
A split view manages the presentation of multiple adjacent panes of content, each of which can contain a variety of components, including tables, collections, images, and custom views.

content.description: A stylized illustration showing a split view interface concept. The image displays a rectangular container divided into sections representing panes. The illustration uses Apple's signature clean, minimal design style with soft colors. There appear to be abstract representations of content areas - including what looks like a sidebar area on the left, and content areas showing abstract shapes representing lists, images, and content blocks. The color palette includes soft pinks, oranges, and neutral tones. The illustration conveys the concept of adjacent content panes working together in a split view layout.
content.composition: Horizontal layout showing multiple adjacent panes with abstract content representations
content.technicalDetails: Vector illustration style consistent with Apple HIG documentation
content.contextualRelevance: Hero image introducing the split view concept visually before detailed text explanation
content.altText: A stylized illustration of a split view interface

content.text: Typically, you use a split view to show multiple levels of your app's hierarchy at once and support navigation between them. In this scenario, selecting an item in the view's primary pane displays the item's contents in the secondary pane. Similarly, a split view can display a tertiary pane if items in the secondary pane contain additional content.

It's common to use a split view to display a sidebar for navigation, where the leading pane lists the top-level items or collections in an app, and the secondary and optional tertiary panes can present child collections and item details. Rarely, you might also use a split view to provide groups of functionality that supplement the primary view — for example, Keynote in macOS uses split view panes to present the slide navigator, the presenter notes, and the inspector pane in areas that surround the main slide canvas.
Best practices

To support navigation, persistently highlight the current selection in each pane that leads to the detail view. The selected appearance clarifies the relationship between the content in various panes and helps people stay oriented.

formatting.boldText: To support navigation, persistently highlight the current selection in each pane that leads to the detail view.

content.text: Consider letting people drag and drop content between panes. Because a split view provides access to multiple levels of hierarchy, people can conveniently move content from one part of your app to another by dragging items to different panes. For guidance, see Drag and drop.

formatting.boldText: Consider letting people drag and drop content between panes.

content.text: Prefer using a split view in a regular — not a compact — environment. A split view needs horizontal space in which to display multiple panes. In a compact environment, such as iPhone in portrait orientation, it's difficult to display multiple panes without wrapping or truncating the content, making it less legible and harder to interact with.

formatting.boldText: Prefer using a split view in a regular — not a compact — environment.

content.text: Platform considerations
iOS

Prefer using a split view in a regular — not a compact — environment. A split view needs horizontal space in which to display multiple panes. In a compact environment, such as iPhone in portrait orientation, it's difficult to display multiple panes without wrapping or truncating the content, making it less legible and harder to interact with.

formatting.boldText: Prefer using a split view in a regular — not a compact — environment.

content.text: iPadOS
In iPadOS, a split view can include either two vertical panes, like Mail, or three vertical panes, like Keynote.

content.description: Two side-by-side illustrations showing iPad split view layouts. The left illustration shows a two-pane split view layout (similar to Mail app) with a narrower left pane (sidebar) and a wider right pane (content area). The right illustration shows a three-pane split view layout (similar to Keynote) with three vertical sections - a narrow left pane, a middle pane, and a right content pane. Both illustrations use abstract geometric shapes and blocks to represent content areas, with subtle color coding to distinguish the different panes.
content.composition: Two illustrations placed horizontally side by side, showing different pane configurations
content.technicalDetails: Vector illustrations showing iPad split view configurations
content.contextualRelevance: Visual examples of two-pane and three-pane split view layouts on iPadOS
content.altText: Illustrations showing two-pane and three-pane split view layouts on iPad

content.text: Account for narrow, compact, and intermediate window widths. Since iPad windows are fluidly resizable, it's important to consider the design of a split view layout at multiple widths. In particular, ensure that it's possible to navigate between the various panes in a logical way. For guidance, see Layout. For developer guidance, see NavigationSplitView and UISplitViewController.

formatting.boldText: Account for narrow, compact, and intermediate window widths.

content.text: macOS

In macOS, you can arrange the panes of a split view horizontally, vertically, or both. A split view includes dividers between panes that can support dragging to resize them. For developer guidance, see HSplitView and VSplitView.

content.description: An illustration showing a macOS split view with horizontal pane arrangement. The image shows a macOS window with multiple vertical panes arranged horizontally (side by side). There's a divider between the panes that can be dragged to resize. The illustration uses abstract representations of content within each pane - possibly showing a sidebar on the left and content areas to the right. There's also an indicator showing 'Multiple' suggesting the ability to have more than two panes.
content.composition: Single macOS window illustration showing horizontally arranged panes
content.technicalDetails: Vector illustration of macOS split view interface
content.contextualRelevance: Visual example of horizontal split view arrangement in macOS
content.altText: Illustration of macOS split view with horizontal pane arrangement

content.text: Set reasonable defaults for minimum and maximum pane sizes. If people can resize the panes in your app's split view, make sure to use sizes that keep the divider visible. If a pane gets too small, the divider can seem to disappear, becoming difficult to use.

formatting.boldText: Set reasonable defaults for minimum and maximum pane sizes.

content.text: Consider letting people hide a pane when it makes sense. If your app includes an editing area, for example, consider letting people hide other panes to reduce distractions or allow more room for editing — in Keynote, people can hide the navigator and presenter notes panes when they want to edit slide content.

formatting.boldText: Consider letting people hide a pane when it makes sense.

content.text: Provide multiple ways to reveal hidden panes. For example, you might provide a toolbar button or a menu command — including a keyboard shortcut — that people can use to restore a hidden pane.

formatting.boldText: Provide multiple ways to reveal hidden panes.

content.text: Prefer the thin divider style. The thin divider measures one point in width, giving you maximum space for content while remaining easy for people to use. Avoid using thicker divider styles unless you have a specific need. For example, if both sides of a divider present table rows that use strong linear elements that might make a thin divider hard to distinguish, it might work to use a thicker divider. For developer guidance, see NSSplitView.DividerStyle.
tvOS
In tvOS, a split view can work well to help people filter content. When people choose a filter category in the primary pane, your app can display the results in the secondary pane.

Choose a split view layout that keeps the panes looking balanced. By default, a split view devotes a third of the screen width to the primary pane and two-thirds to the secondary pane, but you can also specify a half-and-half layout.

formatting.boldText: Choose a split view layout that keeps the panes looking balanced.

content.text: Display a single title above a split view, helping people understand the content as a whole. People already know how to use a split view to navigate and filter content; they don't need titles that describe what each pane contains.

formatting.boldText: Display a single title above a split view, helping people understand the content as a whole.

content.text: Choose the title's alignment based on the type of content the secondary pane contains. Specifically, when the secondary pane contains a content collection, consider centering the title in the window. In contrast, if the secondary pane contains a single main view of important content, consider placing the title above the primary view to give the content more room.

formatting.boldText: Choose the title's alignment based on the type of content the secondary pane contains.

content.text: visionOS

Prefer a split view — not a new window — for offering supplementary information. A split view gives people convenient access to more information without leaving the current context. Opening new windows to show details related to the current window makes it hard to understand relationships and manage window placement. If you need to request a small amount of information or present a simple task that someone must complete before returning to their main task, consider using a sheet.

formatting.boldText: Prefer a split view — not a new window — for offering supplementary information.

content.text: watchOS
In watchOS, the split view displays either the list view or a detail view as a full-screen view.

Automatically display the most relevant detail view. When your app launches, show people the most pertinent information. For example, display information relevant to their location, the time, or their recent actions.

formatting.boldText: Automatically display the most relevant detail view.

content.text: If your app displays multiple detail pages, place the detail views in a vertical tab view. People can then use the Digital Crown to scroll between the detail view's tabs. watchOS also displays a page indicator next to the Digital Crown, indicating the number of tabs and the currently selected tab.

formatting.boldText: If your app displays multiple detail pages, place the detail views in a vertical tab view.

pages.pageSummary: This page is the Apple Developer Documentation for Split views, a UI component for managing multiple adjacent panes of content. It covers best practices for navigation highlighting, drag-and-drop between panes, and preferring split views in regular (not compact) environments. Platform-specific guidance is provided for iOS, iPadOS (with illustrations of 2-pane and 3-pane layouts), macOS (horizontal/vertical arrangements with resizable dividers), tvOS (filtering content), visionOS (preferring split views over new windows), and watchOS (full-screen list/detail views with Digital Crown navigation). Resources include links to related HIG topics (Sidebars, Tab bars, Layout), developer documentation (NavigationSplitView, UISplitViewController, NSSplitViewController), and a WWDC video. A change log tracks documentation updates.

sections.title: Split views
sections.summary: Introduction to split views as a UI component for managing multiple adjacent panes of content, with explanation of typical use cases including hierarchy navigation and sidebar-based navigation patterns.

sections.title: Best practices
sections.summary: Three key best practices: (1) persistently highlight current selection for navigation, (2) consider drag-and-drop between panes, (3) prefer split views in regular (not compact) environments.

sections.title: Platform considerations

subsections.title: iOS
subsections.summary: Guidance to prefer split views in regular environments, noting compact environments like iPhone portrait make multiple panes difficult.

subsections.title: iPadOS
subsections.summary: iPadOS supports 2-pane (like Mail) or 3-pane (like Keynote) layouts. Guidance to account for fluid window resizing and ensure logical pane navigation.

subsections.title: macOS
subsections.summary: macOS supports horizontal, vertical, or combined pane arrangements with draggable dividers. Guidance covers pane size defaults, hiding panes, revealing hidden panes, and preferring thin divider style.

subsections.title: tvOS
subsections.summary: Split views help filter content. Guidance covers balanced pane layouts (1/3-2/3 or half-and-half), single title display, and title alignment based on content type.

subsections.title: visionOS
subsections.summary: Prefer split views over new windows for supplementary information to maintain context and avoid window management complexity.

subsections.title: watchOS
subsections.summary: Split views show list or detail as full-screen views. Guidance covers showing relevant detail on launch and using vertical tab views with Digital Crown for multiple detail pages.

sections.summary: Platform-specific implementation guidance for iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, visionOS, and watchOS, each with unique considerations for their form factor and interaction paradigms.

sections.title: Resources
sections.summary: Links to related HIG topics (Sidebars, Tab bars, Layout), developer documentation (SwiftUI NavigationSplitView, UIKit UISplitViewController, AppKit NSSplitViewController), and WWDC video content.

sections.title: Change log
sections.summary: Documentation revision history showing three updates: June 2025 (iOS/iPadOS), December 2023 (visionOS), and June 2023 (watchOS).

semanticStructure.documentFlow: The document begins with an introduction defining split views and their primary use case (hierarchical navigation). It proceeds to best practices applicable across platforms, then provides detailed platform-specific considerations for six Apple platforms (iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, visionOS, watchOS). The document concludes with resources including related documentation, developer APIs, and video content, followed by a change log tracking documentation updates.

keyTerms.definition: A UI component that manages the presentation of multiple adjacent panes of content, supporting hierarchical navigation and sidebar-based layouts
An individual content area within a split view, can be primary, secondary, or tertiary
The leading pane in a split view, typically containing top-level navigation items or filter categories
The middle or detail pane showing content selected from the primary pane
An optional third pane for additional detail content
A navigation element commonly implemented as the leading pane in a split view, listing top-level items or collections
The visual separator between panes that can support dragging for resizing in macOS
A size class with sufficient horizontal space to display multiple panes (e.g., iPad, iPhone landscape)
A size class with limited horizontal space where multiple panes would be difficult to display (e.g., iPhone portrait)
SwiftUI component for implementing split view navigation
UIKit class for implementing split view interfaces on iOS and iPadOS
AppKit class for implementing split view interfaces on macOS
SwiftUI component for horizontal split view arrangement on macOS
SwiftUI component for vertical split view arrangement on macOS
AppKit enum defining divider appearance options (thin vs thick)
watchOS input method used to scroll between detail view tabs in split view
watchOS component for organizing multiple detail pages that can be navigated via Digital Crown
